pages.name: deceasedPage

elements.name: deceasedIntroExplanation
elements.title:
First, this service will ask about the person who died. All the questions revolve around them. This service will ask about you, the applicant(s), in a later step.

Use the information from their death certificate to help you answer some of the questions.

elements.name: deceasedName
elements.title: What is the name of the person who died?
elements.description: This is the spelling that you want on the Representation Grant for the person who died.

elements.name: deceasedNameFAQ1
elements.title: What if the {deceasedName} used more than one spelling or version of their name?
elements.body: This service will ask you for other spellings of {deceasedName}'s name in a later step. This includes different versions, for example, leaving out their middle names.

elements.name: deceasedNameFAQ2
elements.title: What if {deceasedName}'s name is originally in a different language?
elements.body: You will need to write the English translation of {deceasedName}'s name. Supreme Court of British Columbia forms need to be completed in the English language.

elements.name: deceasedNameReplace
elements.title: Would you like this service to replace {deceasedName}'s name with a nickname?
elements.description: This nickname is only to make your experience with this service more personalized. This nickname will not appear on the Representation Grant.

elements.name: deceasedNickname
elements.title: What is the nickname you would like to see instead of {deceasedName}?
elements.description: You can use anything you like, for example, "your husband" or "Uncle Guy" or "Cousin Nereid". You can always come back to change this at any time.

elements.name: deceasedDateOfDeath
elements.title: What is the date of death on {deceasedName}'s death certificate?

elements.name: deceasedDateOfDeathTrello
elements.title: Trello Card - Date: Set Earliest/Latest Dates

elements.name: deceasedAddress
elements.title: Where did {deceasedName} live?
elements.description: Use the address where Deceased Name spent the majority of their time.

elements.name: deceasedAddressFAQ1
elements.title: What if {deceasedName} was homeless?
elements.body: If {deceasedName} was homeless, write "no fixed address" for the street number and street name.

elements.name: deceasedAddressTrello
elements.title: Trello - Deceased Address: Add Street Address Label and Get rid of Ghost Text

elements.name: firstNations
elements.title: Was {deceasedName} a Nisga'a citizen or a member of a Treaty First Nation?

elements.name: firstNationsName
elements.title: Which of the following applied to {deceasedName}?

elements.name: firstNationsNameTrello
elements.title: Trello - Radio Logic: notempty not working

elements.name: deceasedExitPanel
deceasedExitExplanation
elements.title: Next, we will ask about any wills that {deceasedName} may have made.

pages.title: {deceasedName}'s Information
pages.description: We have questions about the person who died. Make sure you have the information from their death certificate to help you answer some of the questions.

elements.name: willIntroExplanation
elements.title:
Next, this service will ask if {deceasedName} made a `Will`.

If they made a Will, the following questions will check if it is valid and if there are `other testamentary documents`.

elements.name: willCheck
elements.title: Have you diligently searched the places where {deceasedName} would have kept important documents?
elements.description: You are responsible for making sure if {deceasedName} made a Will or not.

elements.name: willCheckFAQ1
elements.title: What is a diligent search?
elements.body:
A diligent search is checking all the places where {deceasedName} usually kept their documents.

You may not find their Will but you may find clues to where the Will is kept. The Will may be at a variety of places, including their home, their safety deposit box, or at the office of the lawyer who helped create the Will.

If you checked all the places and followed all the clues, this is considered a diligent search.

elements.name: willCheckYesExplanation
elements.title:
In addition to diligently searching on your own, you will also need to get a "Search of Wills Notice". You do not need to get this right away to continue with this service, but you will eventually need to provide the results.

You get a "Search of Wills Notice" from the [link?] Vital Statistics Agency of British Columbia. If {deceasedName} registered a Will, the "Search of Wills Notice" will have information about the location of the Will.

The "Search of Wills Notice" must include a search of all of the different names and spellings that {deceasedName} used in their Will and for their assets. If you need help identifying all of the different names and spellings of the deceased, this service will guide you through that process in a later step.

elements.name: willCheckNoError
elements.title:
If you have not diligently searched yet, please do so before continuing with this service. This makes all the difference in what questions this service will ask you.

In addition to diligently searching on your own, you will also need to get a "Search of Wills Notice" and eventually provide the results.

You get a "Search of Wills Notice" from the [link?] Vital Statistics Agency of British Columbia. If {deceasedName} registered a Will, the "Search of Wills Notice" will have information about the location of the Will.

The "Search of Wills Notice" must include a search of all of the different names and spellings that {deceasedName} used in their Will and for their assets. If you need help identifying all of the different names and spellings of the deceased, this service will guide you through that process in a later step.

elements.name: willExists
elements.title: Did {deceasedName} make a `Will`

elements.name: willExistsFAQ1
elements.title: What if I believe {deceasedName} made a will but I/we cannot find it?
elements.body:
If you cannot confirm that a Will exists, you have to decide how you want to proceed. 

The first option is to continue searching for a Will. Do not select "Yes" to this question unless you can confirm a Will exists.

The other option is to select "No" to this question. If you discover a Will later, it can still be recognized. [???consistent language]

elements.name: willExistsFAQ2
elements.title: What if I/we don't know if the Will is valid or not?
elements.body:
If you don't know if {deceasedName}'s Will is valid or not, select "Yes". This service will ask questions to check if the Will is valid.

If necessary, this service may ask if {deceasedName} made more than one Will.

elements.name: otherDocExists
elements.title: Did {deceasedName} make any `other testamentary documents` or recordings?
elements.description: If {deceasedName} made an invalid Will, select "Yes" to this question.

elements.name: otherDocRecognize
elements.title: Do you want to have these `other testamentary documents` recognized as {deceasedName}'s `Will`?

elements.name: otherDocRecognizeNoReasons
elements.title:
Explain why you think each of {deceasedName}'s `other testamentary documents` are not valid or not relevant: Trello: Add Other for Pulldown or Radio
Field2: reason: radio with other. radio options: cannot find the will to which codicil relates; does not reflect deceased's final intention; working draft/draft document; unwitnessed draft; [Reminder] A copy of the testamentary document(s) is attached as an exhibit to the affidavit.

elements.name: otherDocRecognizeYesExplanation
elements.title: If you want a document with issues to be recognized, this service will ask questions to identify the issues.

elements.name: question155
elements.title: Multiple Wills

elements.name: willMultiple
elements.title: Did {deceasedName} make more than one Will?
elements.description: This includes making a new Will to replace an older one.

elements.name: willMultipleFAQ1
elements.title: Do I/we include `other testamentary documents`?
elements.body:
No. This question is only about the Will.

If {deceasedName} made a `codicil` or `other testamentary documents`, this service will ask about those documents later.

elements.name: willRevoked
elements.title: Did {deceasedName}'s latest Will replace their older Wills?
elements.description: Look at the will. Usually at the beginning. "This is the last will and revokes/replaces all previous wills" or similar wording.

elements.name: willRevokedYesExplanation
elements.title:
If {deceasedName} made a new Will that replaced an older one, answer the following questions using information from the most recent Will. If their most recent Will is valid, you will not need to answer questions about old Wills.

If {deceasedName}'s most recent Will has any issues, this service may ask about their next most recent Will.

elements.name: willDifferentAssets
elements.title: Did {deceasedName} make more than one `Will` that each deal with different `assets`

elements.name: willDifferentAssetsNoExplanation
elements.title:
[No - Super Rare]
Start by answering the following questions with information from {deceasedName}'s most recent Will first. This service will have questions about the older Wills separately. [Trigger a series of questions: Ask questions about the existence of the older one(s)? 1. Date made. 2. Alias. Nothing else. 3. Does this revoke a previous will? ifNo. 4. Is there a previous will?
reminders to make copies as well.] [In the other successors page, ask if prior wills list any other executors, beneficiaries etc].

elements.name: willAdministerMultiple
elements.title: Did you want to administer more than one of {deceasedName}'s Wills?

elements.name: willAdministerMultipleNoExplanation
elements.title:
[No]
Answer the following questions using information from the Will that deals with the assets that you wish to administer. [??revisit with consistent language].

elements.name: willAdministerMultipleYesExplanation
elements.title:
[Yes]
If {deceasedName} made more than one Will that each deal with different property/assets, you will have to apply for more than one Representation Grant, for each will.

elements.name: question187
elements.title:
Part 1: ORDER(S) SOUGHT

The petitioner(s) seek(s) the following order under section 58 (2) (a) of the Wills, Estates and Succession Act:

[indent] 1 that the attached record, document or writing represents the testamentary intentions of a deceased person

elements.name: question188
elements.title:
Part 2: FACTUAL BASIS

[Using numbered paragraphs, set out the material facts on which this petition is based.]
1
2

elements.name: question189
elements.title:
What are the facts?
(you/someone else will need support these facts with evidence such affidavits or other documents)
elements.description:
[Description]The key question is whether the document records a deliberate or fixed and final expression of intention as to the disposal of the deceased’s property on death. A deliberate or fixed and final intention is not the equivalent of an irrevocable intention, given that a will, by its nature, is revocable until the death of its maker. Rather, the intention must be fixed and final at the material time, which will vary depending on the circumstances.

[Reference: https://www.canlii.org/en/bc/bcsc/doc/2019/2019bcsc2040/2019bcsc2040.html?searchUrlHash=AAAAAQAoc2VjdGlvbiA1OCB3aWxscywgZXN0YXRlcyBhbmQgc3VjY2Vzc2lvbgAAAAAB&resultIndex=5]

elements.name: question190
elements.title:
Part 3: LEGAL BASIS
[Using numbered paragraphs, specify any rule or other enactment relied on and provide a brief summary of any other legal bases on which the petitioner(s) intend(s) to rely in support of the orders sought.] Para1 1 Section 58 of WESA empowers the court to give the relief requested. Court order curing deficiencies 58 (1)In this section, "record" includes data that (a)is recorded or stored electronically, (b)can be read by a person, and (c)is capable of reproduction in a visible form. (2)On application, the court may make an order under subsection (3) if the court determines that a record, document or writing or marking on a will or document represents (a)the testamentary intentions of a deceased person, (b)the intention of a deceased person to revoke, alter or revive a will or testamentary disposition of the deceased person, or (c)the intention of a deceased person to revoke, alter or revive a testamentary disposition contained in a document other than a will. (3)Even though the making, revocation, alteration or revival of a will does not comply with this Act, the court may, as the circumstances require, order that a record or document or writing or marking on a will or document be fully effective as though it had been made (a)as the will or part of the will of the deceased person, (b)as a revocation, alteration or revival of a will of the deceased person, or (c)as the testamentary intention of the deceased person. (4)If an alteration to a will makes a word or provision illegible and the court is satisfied that the alteration was not made in accordance with this Act, the court may reinstate the original word or provision if there is evidence to establish what the original word or provision was.

templateElements.name: spouseDied5DaysAfterFAQ1
templateElements.title: Why does this date matter?
templateElements.body:
In determining who gets part of estate, it is important to know who died first. This may not sound strange, but under the law, if they died less than 5 days after Deceased Name, they are considered to have died before Deceased Name. For more information, refer to Five-day survival rule from the Wills, Estate and Succession Act (WESA).
http://www.bclaws.ca/civix/document/id/complete/statreg/00_09013_01#section10

templateElements.name: childDied5DaysAfter
templateElements.title: Did {panel.childName} die after <Deceased Date of Death + 4 days>?

templateElements.name: childDied5DaysAfterFAQ1
templateElements.title: Why does this date matter?
templateElements.body:
In determining who gets part of estate, it is important to know who died first. This may not sound strange, but under the law, if they died less than 5 days after Deceased Name, they are considered to have died before Deceased Name. For more information, refer to Five-day survival rule from the Wills, Estate and Succession Act (WESA).
http://www.bclaws.ca/civix/document/id/complete/statreg/00_09013_01#section10

elements.name: PrintP1
elements.title:
This is the first review and print page to print the P1 form (to notify successors).

It will generated a PDF that the applicant would download.

It will give instructions on how to notify the successors.

If any changes are made in the prior questions, need to inform applicants they may need to re-notify.
